            <div class="ContentRelatedControl">
             <h2>
              Related Content
             </h2>
            </div>
           </div>
           <div class="ArticleContent" id="ArticleContent1">
            <p>
             <em>
              The following is an excerpt from
             </em>
             <a href="http://www.motherearthnews.com/shopping/detail.aspx?itemnumber=4715" target="_blank" title="Getting the Most from your Wood-Buying Bucks">
              Getting the Most from your Wood-Buying Bucks
             </a>
             <em>
              from American Woodworker (Fox Chapel Publishing, 2010). Along with detailing the most economical way to buy and process lumber,
             </em>
             Getting the Most from your Wood-Buying Bucks
             <em>
              provides a variety of tips, techniques and general wood know-how. This excerpt is from Chapter 2, "Sawing &amp; Milling Great Wood."
             </em>
            </p>
            <p>
             Transforming a long, gnarly plank of rough lumber into a set of perfectly milled boards is immensely satisfying. Not only do you save money, but you become intimate with the character of every precious piece of wood. The biggest benefit, however, is being absolutely certain that your boards are truly flat, straight and square. Thats the solid foundation you need to make accurate cuts, lay out precise joints and glue boards together without gaps. Here are some helpful pointers to build that foundation.
            </p>
            <h2>
             Cut Off the Ends First
            </h2>
            <p>
             Cracks in a boards ends are a common flaw. Cut them off before you do any other crosscutting, so you know the true, usable length of your board. These cracks are also called end checks. Large checks are easy to see and remove, but you may also find hairline cracks that arent easily visible on the boards surface or end.
            </p>
            <p>
             I cut off the end of a board a little bit at a time, like slicing a loaf of bread. The slices are about 1/4 inch thick. As each slice falls off, I inspect it for checks. If the slice breaks very easily across the grain, it probably contains a hairline check.
            </p>
            <h2>
             Let Boards Rest
            </h2>
            <p>
             To make pieces dead flat, I usually let boards rest before taking them down to final thickness. I plane boards 1/8 inch thicker than needed and stack them with stickers or stand them on edge so air can circulate around every side.
            </p>
            <p>
             After the boards rest for a day or so, I check each board for flatness by laying it on my tablesaw or jointer. Its not unusual to find that some previously flat boards have cupped or twisted a bit. I rejoint one side of these boards, then plane every board to final thickness.
            </p>
            <h2>
             Cut Big Boards into Small Pieces
            </h2>
            <p>
             You might think the best strategy for milling rough lumber is to flatten as large a piece as possible, then cut it into smaller parts. Not true. Its better to cut a big roughsawn board into individual pieces, one for each part on your cutting list, more or less, and then start milling. Cut oversize by 1/2 inch of length and 1/4 inch of width.
            </p>
            <p>
             The problem with the big-board strategy is that the smaller pieces may not end up flat or straight. Some boards have a lot of internal stress. When the board is whole, all this stress is in balance. When you rip the board, you release some of that stress. Each piece seeks a new balance and a new shape. A flat, straight board ripped down the middle might well make two boards that arent flat or straight. Its hard to predict which boards will react this way.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="ArticleContent" id="ArticleContent2">
            <h2>
             Follow the Grain
            </h2>
            <p>
             Im sure youve seen boards like the one at right whose grain runs off the edge in a bad way. If that board becomes part of a project, its slanting grain stands out like a sore thumb. I prefer to eliminate this problem at the outset, while the board is still rough. When Ive got this type of board, and enough width to spare, I cut a new edge that more truly follows the grain.
            </p>
            <p>
             I prefer to use the bandsaw for ripping rough lumber, but a circular saw works well, too. If youre ripping long boards on the bandsaw, use a tall support on the outfeed side to steady the workpiece.
            </p>
            <h2>
             Mark Grain Direction
            </h2>
            <p>
             As Im jointing the faces of rough boards, I always mark grain direction on the boards end. This mark tells me to start the cut here on the nearest face. This line wont be removed by jointing or planing.
            </p>
            <p>
             When I stack boards for planing, I look at the marks and orient them all the same way: face down and pointing away from the planer. Even if the boards fall onto the floor as they come out of the machine, I can easily reassemble them with the grain all going the same way, and get right back to work.
            </p>
            <h2>
             Avoid Badly Twisted Boards
            </h2>
            <p>
             Some twisted boards are hopeless causes. You might just as well turn them into firewood. Sure, you can joint them flat, but a few rogue boards have a nasty habit of slowly continuing to twist, no matter how many times theyre jointed or how short or narrow you cut them.
            </p>
            <p>
             If your rough lumber is only slightly twisted, however, dont get too alarmed. It doesnt mean youve got junk wood. It may remain perfectly stable after its milled. Just cut it as short and narrow as you can in the rough state  but not less than 12 inches long  to get the maximum yield in thickness.
            </p>
            <h2>
             Use the Best Crosscutting Tools
            </h2>
            <p>
             Rough lumber can be tricky to crosscut safely. Its faces and edges are rarely flat and straight, so using a chop saw, miter saw or tablesaw is not the best practice, because the blade could bind, stall, or kick back.
            </p>
            <p>
             My favorite tools for crosscutting are a jigsaw, a circular saw and a Japanese tree-trimming saw. This very coarse handsaw cuts incredibly fast, even through thick hardwoods.
            </p>
            <p>
             I generally crosscut before doing any jointing or planing. Crosscutting reduces a big board to more manageable sizes, so I can mill more accurately. I put my board on four sawhorses for plenty of support and mark it with chalk, a felt-tip pen, or a carpenters soft-leaded pencil.
            </p>
            <hr/>
            <h2>
             Skip Plane To Reveal Grain
            </h2>
            <p>
             What exactly is under that rough surface? Sometimes its quite difficult to read the grain, spot defects or figure out where the sapwood lies in a roughsawn board  all the things youd want to know before cutting it up.
            </p>
            <p>
             If Im stumped, I run the whole board through the planer. I plane just enough to remove the high spots and skip over the low spots. I dont need to see an entirely planed surface to mark up the board for cutting into smaller pieces.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="ArticleContent" id="ArticleContent3">
            <p>
             When the board comes out of the planer, I dont assume its flat. Ill cut it up into smaller pieces and joint one face of every piece before running it through the planer again. You lose a bit of the boards maximum thickness when you skip plane, but thats usually no big deal.
            </p>
            <p>
            </p>
            <hr/>
            <p>
            </p>
            <p>
             <em>
              Reprinted with permission from
             </em>
             <a href="http://www.motherearthnews.com/shopping/detail.aspx?itemnumber=4715" target="_blank" title="Getting the Most from your Wood-Buying Bucks">
              Getting the Most from your Wood-Buying Bucks
             </a>
             <em>
              , published by Fox Chapel Publishing, 2010.
             </em>
            </p>
           </div>

         <script type="text/javascript">
          MaxId = 'browserv2_0_articleleftcolumnv1_1_Max';
    CurId = 'browserv2_0_articleleftcolumnv1_1_Cur';

    function Init() {
        Clear();
        var SlideNumber = GetQueryString('SlideShow');
        var Max = parseInt(document.getElementById(MaxId).value);
        if (SlideNumber == null || SlideNumber &gt; Max) {
            SlideNumber = 1;
        }

        var SlideId = 'Slide' + SlideNumber;
        var Slide = document.getElementById(SlideId);
        if (Slide == null) {
            Slide = document.getElementById("Slide1");
        }

        Slide.style.display = 'block';
        var Cur = document.getElementById(CurId);
        Cur.value = SlideNumber;

        document.getElementById('ImageCounter').innerHTML = 'Image: ' + SlideNumber + ' of ' + Max;
        SetUrl(SlideNumber);
    }

    function Clear() {
        var Max = parseInt(document.getElementById(MaxId).value);
        for (var i = 1; i &lt;= Max; i++) {
            var SlideId = "Slide" + i;
            var Slide = document.getElementById(SlideId);
            if (Slide != null) {
                Slide.style.display = 'none';
            }
        }
    }

    function ArrowNext() {
        var Cur = parseInt(document.getElementById(CurId).value);
        var Max = parseInt(document.getElementById(MaxId).value);

        if (Cur &gt;= Max) {
            Cur = 1;
        }
        else {
            Cur = (Cur + 1);
        }

        Clear();

        var SlideId = "Slide" + Cur;
        var Slide = document.getElementById(SlideId);
        if (Slide != null) {
            Slide.style.display = 'block';
            document.getElementById(CurId).value = Cur;
            document.getElementById('ImageCounter').innerHTML = 'Image: ' + Cur + ' of ' + Max;
            SetUrl(Cur);
        }

        googletag.pubads().refresh();
    }

    function ArrowBack() {
        var Cur = parseInt(document.getElementById(CurId).value);
        var Max = parseInt(document.getElementById(MaxId).value);

        if (Cur == 1) {
            Cur = Max;
        }
        else {
            Cur = (Cur - 1);
        }

        Clear();

        var SlideId = "Slide" + Cur;
        var Slide = document.getElementById(SlideId);
        if (Slide != null) {
            Slide.style.display = 'block';
            document.getElementById(CurId).value = Cur;
            document.getElementById('ImageCounter').innerHTML = 'Image: ' + Cur + ' of ' + Max;
            SetUrl(Cur);
        }

        googletag.pubads().refresh();
    }

    function GetQueryString(queryName) {
        var match = RegExp('[?&amp;]' + queryName + '=([^&amp;]*)').exec(window.location.search);
        return match &amp;&amp; decodeURIComponent(match[1].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
    }

    Init();

    function SetUrl(picNumber) {
        try
        {
            var UrlQuery = window.location.pathname;
            UrlQuery = UrlQuery + '?SlideShow=' + picNumber;
            window.history.pushState("", document.title, UrlQuery);
        }
        catch (e)
        {
        }
    }
         </script>

            </div>
            <div class="Body">
             When we bought our TimberKing sawmill we learned a lot of things. 
One if you are sawing boards and begin to see black streaks in the boards, stop. There is some sort of metal, nails, spikes, etc...you will totally ruin your blades.
Two try to avoid using trees from a hilltop or other very windy areas. These tend to twist, warp, and split much more than normal area trees.
Hope this helps.

            <div class="Body">

These boards were a very small amount of trouble for me but a cabinet maker would have used them for winter heat.

       function getWidth() {
            xWidth = null;
            if (window.screen != null)
                xWidth = window.screen.availWidth;

            if (window.innerWidth != null)
                xWidth = window.innerWidth;

            if (document.body != null)
                xWidth = document.body.clientWidth;

            return xWidth;
        }
 var prev_handler = window.onload;

    if (prev_handler) {
        prev_handler();
     }
        window.onload = function(event) {
        var left = parseInt(document.getElementById('LeftLayout').offsetWidth);
        var right = parseInt(document.getElementById('RightLayout').offsetWidth);
        var body = parseInt(document.getElementById('ContentLayout').offsetWidth);
            var content = parseInt(left) + parseInt(right) + parseInt(body);
            var size = parseInt(getWidth()) - 1400;

            if (parseInt(size) &lt; 0) {
                document.getElementById('LeftLayout').style.visibility = 'hidden';
                document.getElementById('RightLayout').style.visibility = 'hidden';
                document.getElementById('LeftLayout').style.display = 'none';
                document.getElementById('RightLayout').style.display = 'none';
            }
            else {
                document.getElementById('LeftLayout').style.visibility = 'visible';
                document.getElementById('RightLayout').style.visibility = 'visible';
                document.getElementById('LeftLayout').style.display = 'block';
                document.getElementById('RightLayout').style.display = 'block';
            }
        }

        window.onresize = function(event) {
